intro: Lippia hemisphaerica, commonly known as the Mexican mint or Mexican tea, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, featuring square, hairy stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are usually white or pale blue, arranged in clusters at the ends of the branches. It is often cultivated for its aromatic leaves, which are used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb. Lippia hemisphaerica thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for gardens in warm climates.
